bibl.title: Letter from Gustaf E. Lambert to Jessie Daniel Ames, July 11, 1937

div1.p: Lambert updates Jessie Ames on his efforts to secure passage of a bill recognizing Roger Ames and others.

div1.head: Letter from Gustaf E. Lambert to Jessie Daniel Ames, July 11, 1937
div1.opener:
From Mrs Ames
COPY
Chicago, Illinois
July 11th
1937 (?)
Mrs. Jessie Daniel Ames
Dear Madam:
div1.p:
It has taken me a long time to get anything to show for my
labor but now it seems to come in a bunch. The enclosed
letters I have just received from Andrus. I'll send just
as I received them so you can see why they have taken so
long to get here.

From Miss Lewis, I haven't heard. I suppose her Congressmen
haven't given her any reply.

I wrote Andrus asking him to formulate a letter demanding
recognition for Dr. Ames and nurse, and get it signed by all
the men who are still living that took part in the experiment
and present the same to the chairman of the Military Affairs
Committee. That's all I have been able to do where both bills
have been directly concerned. But in all my efforts the bill
to recognise Dr. Ames has always been put first and I don't
think Congress would pass one and not the other. I think they
will pass at the same time or not pass at all. If i'm called
to Washington, I promise to do more talking for the Ames' bill
than for mine.

At the State Convention in Moline the U.S.W.V. passed a reso-
lution demanding that all Congressmen from this State use their
best efforts to get my bill passed. Every camp in the state
(131 in number) will contact their individual congressmen urging
the passage of H.R. 4602 (my bill). The Commander of my V.F.W.
Post who returned from the State Convention last night called
and told me resolutions has been passed there, and that over
300 posts would demand passage of H.R. 4602. But best of all
National Commander Kearney who was at the Convention promised
that every Congressman in the House would be contacted through
the National Department of the V.F.W. and asked to pass H.R. 4602.

As it has already passed the Senate twice, I can't help thinking
that our bills will pass at this session.
div1.closer:
Respectfully, (Signed) GeneralGustus E. Lambert 4718 Woodlawn Avenue
P.S. I have misplaced copy of first letter Andrus wrote his
Congressan.
Lambert
